results.title: Zoo Dance
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Tony Paice
results.brief_description: Dance movement programme operates at the Royal Melbourne Zoo. Its aims include encouraging creativity and communication between students and teachers, self-expression, building self confidence. Available to children with disabilities as well as the regular school student.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Ministry of Education and Tony Paice

results.title: Zoo creatures great and small
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Rob McCubbin and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Andrew Tribe, zoo veterinarian, and Jeanne de Lacy, zoo keeper, both from Royal Melbourne Zoological Gardens, Zoo Education Service Staff, are interviewed by Trevor Lunn. Animals come to the zoo, often after car accidents and are examined and treated in the veterinary department or nursery. Training for zoo keepers and zoo veterinarians is discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Rob McCubbin and Jeff Spencer

results.title: Zoo baby animals
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Walker
results.brief_description: Opportunity for children to look behind the scenes at the zoo - to see activities in the kitchen and hospital; how baby animals are fed and cared for by their keepers. Shows many animals in attractive outdoor settings and in “children’s zoo” sections in the famous Lincoln Park and Brookfield Zoos of Chicago. Baby animals featured in the film are the lion, tiger, gorilla, bear, elephant, harbor seal, kudu, llama, Barbary sheep, tapir and baboon.

results.title: Zoo babies: observing things about us
results.brief_description: Designed to teach young children to observe more carefully the things about them. This film compares the habits and physical characteristics of various baby animals at the zoo. Animals studied include monkeys, gnus, lions, peacocks, alligators and bears.

results.title: Zoo babies
results.brief_description: Join Channel TEN’s Lynday Davies as she follows the lives of baby animals at Sydney’s Taronga and Western Plains Zoos. The zoo witnesses the birth of many babies throughout the year, with thousands of new additions to the zoo ‘family’. You’ll see the birth of a baby gorilla and giraffe, as well as an assortment of all creatures great and small who are cared for by zoo staff.

results.title: Zoo animals of our story books
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Background for Social Studies”.
Designed to stimulate young children’s interest in reading stories about animals that can be seen in a zoo. These animals are compared with the character found in storybooks, such as tigers in “Little Black Sambo”, deer in “Bambi” and bears in “Goldilocks and the Three Bears”. The film concludes with an invitation to the children to make up their own story based on the character “Bubble the Elephant”.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: ostriches
results.creator_credit: Coronet Films, Bill Walker and Mel Waskin
results.brief_description: The ostrich is the tallest and heaviest of all bird species, using its feet and sharp talons to protect itself against other animals. Shows the courting behaviour of the male and female ostrich as well as the care of the young. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: lions and tigers
results.brief_description: Shows tigers and lions hunting, fighting and caring for their young, noting the playfulness and curiosity of the cubs. Points out that tigers are related to lions. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: crocodiles
results.brief_description: Notes the physical characteristics of crocodiles such as strong jaws, tough skins and powerful tails; and shows the care of baby crocodiles by the mothers. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Zoo animals in the wild: beavers
results.creator_credit: Coronet Films, Bill Walker and Mel Waskin
results.brief_description: Notes the eating habits of the beaver and shows how it constructs a dam using its sharp front teeth to gnaw away branches, and its rudder-shaped tail and webbed back paws to gather mud to cement the branches together. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
